docs.title: DSP – Data Source Publication
docs.text:
DSP (Data Source Publication) is an open, technology-neutral standard for describing enterprise data sources, datasets, and schemas in a single JSON format.

It lets any system – databases, streams, APIs, files, search, NoSQL, graphs, SaaS platforms – publish a DSP manifest that describes:

  • What data exists (datasets and fields)
  • How it is structured (types, nullability, partitioning)
  • How to access it (SQL, HTTP, topics, paths)
  • Optional business semantics (domains, entity types, join hints, PII)

DSP does not move data. It standardizes metadata so tools, agents, catalogs, and humans can discover and understand data consistently.

docs.title: Repository Layout
docs.text:
• dsp-spec/ – DSP JSON Schema (dsp-1.0.json)
  • dsp-sdk/ – Python SDK with core models and profiles
  • dsp-registry/ – Reference registry service for publishing and discovering manifests
  • examples/ – Example DSP manifests for common data source types
  • docs/ – Documentation site powered by mkdocs

See Getting Started to create your first DSP manifest.

docs.title: DSP Registry Service
docs.text:
The DSP Registry is a small HTTP service that stores and indexes DSP manifests.

It provides:

  • GET /health – health check
  • PUT /dsp/sources/{source_id} – publish or update a manifest
  • GET /dsp/sources – list all sources
  • GET /dsp/sources/{source_id} – get a single manifest
  • GET /dsp/search – simple search over datasets and fields

The reference implementation is in dsp-registry/ and uses FastAPI with an in-memory store (suitable for demos, POCs, and as a blueprint for production).

docs.title: Running the registry
docs.text:
From the dsp-registry directory:

python -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate  # Windows: .venv\Scripts\activate
pip install -e .[dev]
uvicorn app.main:app --reload --port 8080

The API will be available at http://localhost:8080.

Open the interactive docs:

  • http://localhost:8080/docs

docs.title: Publishing a manifest
docs.text:
Assume you have examples/sql_source.json ready:

curl -X PUT   http://localhost:8080/dsp/sources/sql_example   -H "Content-Type: application/json"   --data-binary @../examples/sql_source.json

You should see a JSON response confirming the source was stored.

docs.title: Listing and retrieving manifests
docs.text:
List all sources:

curl http://localhost:8080/dsp/sources

Get a specific manifest:

curl http://localhost:8080/dsp/sources/sql_example

docs.title: Simple search
docs.text:
Search by dataset_id, field_name, or domain:

curl "http://localhost:8080/dsp/search?field_name=id"

The search API is deliberately simple; you can extend it with more fields, filters, and backends (for example a real database or search engine) as needed.

docs.title: DSP Examples
docs.text:
This repository includes example DSP manifests under examples/:

  • sql_source.json – generic relational database / warehouse
  • stream_source.json – generic streaming platform topics
  • api_source.json – generic REST API based on an OpenAPI-like contract
  • file_source.json – generic file-based dataset (for example object storage)
  • graph_source.json – generic graph database with nodes and edges

Each example is intentionally domain-neutral.

You can use these as templates for your own systems:

  1. Copy an example JSON file
  2. Change source_id, connection, datasets, and fields
  3. Validate against dsp-1.0.json
  4. Commit or publish to the registry

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
This guide walks you through:

  1. Creating a DSP manifest
  2. Validating it against the DSP schema
  3. Storing it in Git
  4. (Optionally) publishing it to the DSP Registry

docs.title: 1. Create a minimal DSP manifest
docs.text:
A minimal manifest can be written by hand:

{
  "version": "dsp-1.0",
  "source_id": "example_source",
  "connection": {
    "type": "custom"
  },
  "datasets": [
    {
      "dataset_id": "example_dataset",
      "kind": "custom",
      "fields": [
        { "name": "id", "type": "string" }
      ]
    }
  ]
}

Save as examples/example_source.json.

docs.title: 2. Validate against the DSP schema
docs.text:
From the dsp-spec directory:

pip install jsonschema
jsonschema -i ../examples/example_source.json specs/dsp-1.0.json

If no errors appear, the manifest is valid according to dsp-1.0.

docs.title: 3. Generate manifests with the DSP SDK
docs.text:
Instead of hand-writing manifests, you can use the SDK (Python).

Install the SDK locally:

cd dsp-sdk
python -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate  # Windows: .venv\Scripts\activate
pip install -e .

Then create a manifest for a SQL database:

from sqlalchemy import create_engine
from dsp_sdk.profiles.sql import introspect_sql
from dsp_sdk.core.io import save_source

engine = create_engine("postgresql://user:password@host:5432/dbname")

source = introspect_sql(
    source_id="example_sql_source",
    engine=engine,
    schemas=["public"],
)

save_source(source, "../examples/sql_source.json")

docs.title: 4. Store manifests in Git
docs.text:
Commit your DSP manifests in your own repo:

git add examples/sql_source.json
git commit -m "Add initial DSP manifest"

docs.title: 5. (Optional) Publish to the DSP Registry
docs.text: See Registry Service for how to run the reference registry and publish manifests to it using HTTP.

docs.title: Source Types Cookbook
docs.text:
This page shows how to describe different kinds of enterprise data systems using DSP.

For every system, the pattern is the same:

  1. Define a Source (source_id, connection)
  2. Define one or more Datasets (dataset_id, kind, physical_name)
  3. Define Fields (name, type, nullable, mapping)
  4. Optionally add Semantics (domain, entity_type, PII, join hints)
  5. Optionally add Access metadata (SQL/search/stream/file)

DSP uses one JSON shape for all of them – the difference is mostly in:

  • connection.type
  • connection.driver
  • dataset.kind
  • dataset.access details

You can either hand-write the JSON or use the DSP SDK profiles where available.

(Full cookbook content omitted here for brevity in this comment, but in your actual project you can paste the full Source Types Cookbook as previously generated.)
